tags: but maybe i'm wrong and there's evidence to contradict this
summary: It’s interesting that when people create arya + sansa giftsets of “two sides of the same coin” line that they make sansa related...
body:
It’s interesting that when people create arya + sansa giftsets of “two sides of the same coin” line that they make sansa related to the sun, and arya comparable to the moon. 

for me, the way the characters are, i’ve always seen it as the opposite. arya has always been more related to the sun; pro-sociality (making a great deal of friends with anyone), intensity of friendship, adventure and movement, work and labour. there is always a sense of activity with arya that i generally associate with the sun. 

whereas sansa’s temperament is much more melancholy, immobile (at least narratively speaking), there is definitely a sort of idealism that comes from stories and songs that is highly imaginative…and dreamlike. much more applicable to a still, starry night.

tags: i genuinely want to know your thoughts
summary: I’ve seen several people say that Arya can never have a normal life (like riding off into the sunset with Gendry) because she’s...
body: I’ve seen several people say that Arya can never have a normal life (like riding off into the sunset with Gendry) because she’s this master assasin now. But like…if she survives, and all of the people on her list are dead then she really won’t need to be an assasin anymore. Her list has been her only motivation for killing so once that’s done what else is there for her?

summary: Arya will travel around the world with Gendry discovering new places and training to become a knight as she always wanted
question: Arya will travel around the world with Gendry discovering new places and training to become a knight as she always wanted
answer:
You’re damn right she will! They’ll travel and fight and live and love.

He will be her forest love and she his forest lass.

tags: the house of black and white
caption: you’re mine

summary: one of my favorite scenes from GOT is when Ned asks his boys “and which of you was a marksman at 10?” and they all laugh,...
body: one of my favorite scenes from GOT is when Ned asks his boys “and which of you was a marksman at 10?” and they all laugh, because, after all, none of them were -that would be silly. But then, out of nowhere, Arya -who is almost 10, surprises them by hitting the bullseye from even further away than where the boys were standing. Arya Stark is a marksman at 9 (or 11 if you take the show). We know she’s good because she practiced a hundred times at Winterfell when no one was watching, and then a thousand more on the road with the brotherhood. Just like she practiced with Needle. And I pity the person that underestimates her skill with either weapon.

summary: not that anything in s8 will warrant this discussion but joe and maisie are professionals. they’re adults. they’re on set to do...
body:
not that anything in s8 will warrant this discussion but joe and maisie are professionals. they’re adults. they’re on set to do a job and like the rest of the cast they dont have anymore say in the script then we, as viewers, do. this is d&d’s show we’re *all* at their mercy. just like emilia and kit having a sex scene that made them both uncomfortable bc theyre friends or aiden kissing sophie multiple times even though shes young enough to be his child or 30+ yr old nat dormer having a sex scene with a teen. ect. 

this is their line of work. but again, a completely unnecessary conversation bc 1.  they wrapped. its done. maisie and joes comfort level while filming is in the past and completely irrelevant to the topic of future arya/gendry content 2. im sure nothing happened that made them feel uncomfortable while filming s8 anyway. they were spotted multiple times hanging out together off set. we’ve also seen them both since wrapping and they’ve had nothing but praise for the show, its writers and each other. joe even said he would in fact kiss arya at a GoT con that he happily attended. its all good. so can we not turn this into a thing for literally no reason.

blog.name: fortunatelylori
blog.title: Thoughts on the verge
blog.description:
Pretty much Game of Throne and Jonsa all day, every day. 
Avatar and header by @ragekitn

summary: I think Jon and Sansa are more alike now than Jon and Arya.  I just can't see them being as close as they were as children.  I...
question: I think Jon and Sansa are more alike now than Jon and Arya.  I just can't see them being as close as they were as children.  I can even see Sansa and Arya being closer now than Jon and Arya.  Thoughts?
answer:
Hey, nonnie!

I both agree and disagree on this. :)

Honestly I don’t think Jon and Arya were ever alike or that their bond came down to them being similar people. In book canon, Jon and Arya share the Stark look (Jon looks like Ned and Arya looks like Lyanna) and I suppose you could argue Kit Harrington and Maisie Williams look more like each other than either of them looks like Sophie Turner but that’s about it. 

What Jon and Arya really are is a Ned x Lyanna 2.0. And just like Ned and Lyanna, Jon and Arya aren’t really similar in personality. Ned is quiet, introverted, even shy. He’s the “still waters run deep” type of man. Whereas Lyanna is the extroverted, impulsive sister with a penchant for over-dramatic theatricality (her dressing up as the Knight of the Laughing Tree at the tourney, for example). 

 I’d say Jon and Sansa have always been more alike in behavior, character and worldview. They’re both introverts where Arya is an extrovert. They both dream of a domestic, quiet life where Arya dreams about adventure and finding out “what’s West of Westeros”. Jon is a conformist, just like Sansa, who can’t conform to the standards of the time because he’s a bastard while Arya could fit in pretty nicely in her society because she’s the daughter of a great Lord but can’t because her interests and desires push her to buck convention. 

Jon and Arya’s bond comes from their acceptance and support for each other, not their similarities. The one thing they share is the feeling that they’re both outcasts in the Stark family and in society. They are different but they acknowledge each other as individuals and give each other the acceptance that they feel others are denying them. It’s no mistake that in the books Arya thinks Jon will recognize her and love her even when her other family members might not. Because the love that Jon and Arya feel for each other is not conditional on what conventional society expects from them. That’s a really special, beautiful bond. 

I have theorized in the past that Jon and Arya’s relationship might be strained once they’re reunited but I don’t think that would be a permanent issue or that their bond will suffer dramatically. Both Jon and Arya have grown and developed apart for some time now so it would be silly to say that there won’t be any changes to their relationship. Whenever Jon thinks of Arya he thinks of the little sister he remembers, the little girl he said good-bye to in Winterfell. But that little girl has grown now and has gone through harrowing experiences. Arya thinks of Jon as her big brother and her childhood companion but Jon has now been through being a man of the Night’s Watch, Lord Commander and King in the North. He’s not the same kid that left Winterfell either. They’ll both have to get to know each other again and figure out what their relationship now as adults will be like. 

I’ve already stated that in the absence of the political Jon theory, Arya might have some pretty big bones to pick with Jon over his decision to bend the knee and bring D*ny to Winterfell. On the other hand, I think Jon might take issue with Arya’s revenge quest and her list. We’ve already seen how he reacted to Sansa proposing to take Last Hearth and Karhold from Ned Umber and Alys Karstark. 

Wholesale revenge and cruelty are not things Jon prescribes to. He can be ruthless at times (his Wildling plot), use violence when he feels he needs to (the execution of Janos Slynt) but the type of violence that Arya has been engaged in I think will give him pause. That doesn’t mean he’ll reject her or stop loving her but I do think these traits will cause him concern and might result in them clashing. However, those strains will be temporary. Arya’s entire journey has been leading her back to Winterfell, and most particularly to Jon. Whereas she might not care whether Sansa might be shocked by the list of people she wants to kill (although her insecure look back at Sansa when Bran mentioned the list is an indication that she does care), she most definitely will care what Jon thinks. I imagine that will lead her to reexamine her actions and her behavior and hopefully find a balance between the brilliant warrior and the empathetic, sweet girl she still is deep down. 

As for Sansa and Arya … I don’t know about them being closer to each other than Jon and Arya but I do think they’ll be closer than what we saw in season 7. That was the promise made at the end of the last season and probably the only saving grace of that whole Winterfell plot line. Also, considering the comments made by both Sophie and Maisie about Sansa and Arya making a good team, I think there’s reason to hope that Arya and Sansa will finally come together as individuals, love and respect each other and fight for one another as a pack. 

I was also surprised that in the new teaser, Arya and Sansa share a look but Arya doesn’t share one with Jon. I don’t think we should infer much of anything regarding the Jon/Arya relationship from that because it’s one of the big payoffs of the show so they’d probably want to keep what happens between them pretty close to the vest but that look that Sansa and Arya share does give me hope that we’ll have the healthy, beautiful sister bond we’ve all been dreaming about from season 8 Sansa and Arya. 

Thanks for the ask, nonnie!

That doesn’t mean he’ll reject her or stop loving her but I do think these traits will cause him concern and might result in them clashing. However, those strains will be temporary. Arya’s entire journey has been leading her back to Winterfell, and most particularly to Jon. Whereas she might not care whether Sansa might be shocked by the list of people she wants to kill (although her insecure look back at Sansa when Bran mentioned the list is an indication that she does care), she most definitely will care what Jon thinks. I imagine that will lead her to reexamine her actions and her behavior and hopefully find a balance between the brilliant warrior and the empathetic, sweet girl she still is deep down. 

As for Sansa and Arya … I don’t know about them being closer to each other than Jon and Arya but I do think they’ll be closer than what we saw in season 7. That was the promise made at the end of the last season and probably the only saving grace of that whole Winterfell plot line. Also, considering the comments made by both Sophie and Maisie about Sansa and Arya making a good team, I think there’s reason to hope that Arya and Sansa will finally come together as individuals, love and respect each other and fight for one another as a pack. 

I was also surprised that in the new teaser, Arya and Sansa share a look but Arya doesn’t share one with Jon. I don’t think we should infer much of anything regarding the Jon/Arya relationship from that because it’s one of the big payoffs of the show so they’d probably want to keep what happens between them pretty close to the vest but that look that Sansa and Arya share does give me hope that we’ll have the healthy, beautiful sister bond we’ve all been dreaming about from season 8 Sansa and Arya. 

Thanks for the ask, nonnie!
trail.content:
Hey, nonnie!

I both agree and disagree on this. :)

Honestly I don’t think Jon and Arya were ever alike or that their bond came down to them being similar people. In book canon, Jon and Arya share the Stark look (Jon looks like Ned and Arya looks like Lyanna) and I suppose you could argue Kit Harrington and Maisie Williams look more like each other than either of them looks like Sophie Turner but that’s about it. 

What Jon and Arya really are is a Ned x Lyanna 2.0. And just like Ned and Lyanna, Jon and Arya aren’t really similar in personality. Ned is quiet, introverted, even shy. He’s the “still waters run deep” type of man. Whereas Lyanna is the extroverted, impulsive sister with a penchant for over-dramatic theatricality (her dressing up as the Knight of the Laughing Tree at the tourney, for example). 

 I’d say Jon and Sansa have always been more alike in behavior, character and worldview. They’re both introverts where Arya is an extrovert. They both dream of a domestic, quiet life where Arya dreams about adventure and finding out “what’s West of Westeros”. Jon is a conformist, just like Sansa, who can’t conform to the standards of the time because he’s a bastard while Arya could fit in pretty nicely in her society because she’s the daughter of a great Lord but can’t because her interests and desires push her to buck convention. 

Jon and Arya’s bond comes from their acceptance and support for each other, not their similarities. The one thing they share is the feeling that they’re both outcasts in the Stark family and in society. They are different but they acknowledge each other as individuals and give each other the acceptance that they feel others are denying them. It’s no mistake that in the books Arya thinks Jon will recognize her and love her even when her other family members might not. Because the love that Jon and Arya feel for each other is not conditional on what conventional society expects from them. That’s a really special, beautiful bond. 

I have theorized in the past that Jon and Arya’s relationship might be strained once they’re reunited but I don’t think that would be a permanent issue or that their bond will suffer dramatically. Both Jon and Arya have grown and developed apart for some time now so it would be silly to say that there won’t be any changes to their relationship. Whenever Jon thinks of Arya he thinks of the little sister he remembers, the little girl he said good-bye to in Winterfell. But that little girl has grown now and has gone through harrowing experiences. Arya thinks of Jon as her big brother and her childhood companion but Jon has now been through being a man of the Night’s Watch, Lord Commander and King in the North. He’s not the same kid that left Winterfell either. They’ll both have to get to know each other again and figure out what their relationship now as adults will be like. 

I’ve already stated that in the absence of the political Jon theory, Arya might have some pretty big bones to pick with Jon over his decision to bend the knee and bring D*ny to Winterfell. On the other hand, I think Jon might take issue with Arya’s revenge quest and her list. We’ve already seen how he reacted to Sansa proposing to take Last Hearth and Karhold from Ned Umber and Alys Karstark. 

Wholesale revenge and cruelty are not things Jon prescribes to. He can be ruthless at times (his Wildling plot), use violence when he feels he needs to (the execution of Janos Slynt) but the type of violence that Arya has been engaged in I think will give him pause. That doesn’t mean he’ll reject her or stop loving her but I do think these traits will cause him concern and might result in them clashing. However, those strains will be temporary. Arya’s entire journey has been leading her back to Winterfell, and most particularly to Jon. Whereas she might not care whether Sansa might be shocked by the list of people she wants to kill (although her insecure look back at Sansa when Bran mentioned the list is an indication that she does care), she most definitely will care what Jon thinks. I imagine that will lead her to reexamine her actions and her behavior and hopefully find a balance between the brilliant warrior and the empathetic, sweet girl she still is deep down. 

As for Sansa and Arya … I don’t know about them being closer to each other than Jon and Arya but I do think they’ll be closer than what we saw in season 7. That was the promise made at the end of the last season and probably the only saving grace of that whole Winterfell plot line. Also, considering the comments made by both Sophie and Maisie about Sansa and Arya making a good team, I think there’s reason to hope that Arya and Sansa will finally come together as individuals, love and respect each other and fight for one another as a pack. 

I was also surprised that in the new teaser, Arya and Sansa share a look but Arya doesn’t share one with Jon. I don’t think we should infer much of anything regarding the Jon/Arya relationship from that because it’s one of the big payoffs of the show so they’d probably want to keep what happens between them pretty close to the vest but that look that Sansa and Arya share does give me hope that we’ll have the healthy, beautiful sister bond we’ve all been dreaming about from season 8 Sansa and Arya. 

Thanks for the ask, nonnie!

summary: I have the headcanon that when the girls in Winterfell (Sansa, Jeyne Poole, Beth Cassel etc) bullied her, Arya went to Jon to...
body: I have the headcanon that when the girls in Winterfell (Sansa, Jeyne Poole, Beth Cassel etc) bullied her, Arya went to Jon to find comfort.  Jon would mess her hair and tell her that even if the girls are teasing her for her appearence to him she’s will always look beautiful because she has a beautiful heart.And little Arya would finally be in peace because who cares about the world’s opinion when Jon Snow loves them?

summary: Sophie Turner and the Statue (Comic Con Oct 2018)
body:
Sophie Turner and the Statue (Comic Con Oct 2018)

Back in the Comic Con in October 2018, Sophie Turner let it slip that she wanted to take home a statue that had nothing to do with the series, and I was worried that it meant she was going to die. Now, I understand the statue is the one in the latest teaser. So, does this mean the latest promo actually doesn’t mean she’s going to die and that it has nothing to do with the outcome of the show? Now I am starting to think it really is more of a promo highlighting Jon’s parentage and the Starks coming together to protect him. What do you think?

EDIT: I researched and found some references on said statement from Sophie on the statue last October 2018.

““We did this promo for season eight where – I don’t know if I can say this, actually. Well, actually, no. It’s got nothing to do with the series; it’s just a promo. It was this big kind of statue of me, of Sansa, and I wanted to have it in the garden of my new house. But they obviously wouldn’t ship it from Belfast to New York, so…”

See below an old article which wrote about it back in October last year.

https://goat.com.au/game-of-thrones/between-the-potential-game-of-thrones-spoiler-and-the-weed-related-anecdotes-sophie-turner-was-the-best-thing-at-comic-con?fbclid=IwAR3ylc_U7H4DCQKxpyqIBTx7oVG7oyg2SUAQPgnd1-rlJtA8Z2lR6Y-iFJ8

summary: Since Dany grew up in a much warmer climate the cold North is a drastic change for her. She clenches her jaw until it almost...
body: Since Dany grew up in a much warmer climate the cold North is a drastic change for her. She clenches her jaw until it almost breaks to stop from shivering. She wraps up in tons of layers and her bed is just a heap of blankets. She always hovers near the fires to stay warm. One day, when the cold clings to her bones, she holds her hand so close that the flames lick her fingers. She’s, of course, unbothered by the heat. Arya watches from across the hall, her eyes wide with intrigue. When Dany notices the stares coming from a dark corner she slowly plunges her whole forearm into the flame. Dany smiles at her as she enjoys the heat. Arya beams back at the unburnt queen.
